channel.title: Client GUI Editing
channel.description: I've googled and searched all over but can't find anything about this. I've just started coding clients today and i'm trying to find out what i can do and how. I've messed up plenty but fixed all the errors and figured out how to do many things through trial and error but now i'm stuck trying to move the chatbox. I've tried to edit the sprites and make the chat box bigger and the surrounding sprites smaller, i was accurate down to the pixel but was just left with empty space between them. I tried to manually set the grab pixel arguments in Class30_Sub2_Sub1_Sub1 (Seemingly where the interface is set up in my client). Now what i'm wondering is how do i determine how big a sprite is and where it's put on the interface? I've never taken java lessons and i'm pretty new to it so be gentle ^^.

item.title: Client GUI Editing
item.dc:creator: @Maxammus Maxammus
item.description:
@Maxammus wrote:

What exactly do you mean by that? When i delete part the surrounding sprites they just move in closer to the chat box and leave a blank space where they should be and the chat doesn’t change at all. How would i change where the sprites are kept on the interface?

Read full topic

item.title: Client GUI Editing
item.dc:creator: @gamma gamma
item.description:
@gamma wrote:

The size of A spirite such as the Chatback, Would be according to the sizes of the surrounding Spirites.

Read full topic

item.title: Client GUI Editing
item.dc:creator: @Nuke207 Nuke207
item.description:
@Nuke207 wrote:

Welcome to Runescape Coding then? Enjoy your stay. Sorry i can’t help ya , I would but I’m a noob at java ATM

Read full topic

item.title: Client GUI Editing

I’ve googled and searched all over but can’t find anything about this. I’ve just started coding clients today and i’m trying to find out what i can do and how. Now what i’m wondering is how do i determine how big a sprite is and where it’s put on the interface? I’ve never taken java lessons and i’m pretty new to it so be gentle ^^.
